snippet.textDisplay: Apparently the judges in Texas score fights on the old rules, which heavily weigh octagon control (or allow judges to heavily weigh it). And Jones was moving forward practically the entire fight, even though for the first 3 rounds he was getting bombed. That's the only rational explanation I can conceive for the one judge's result. I still think Reyes won, and that judge's score was ridiculous. As for weighing the last two "championship" rounds more, I don't agree with that, because then that always allows the champion to do little for the first three rounds and save it all for the last two. I feel that in a 5 round fight, there's no excuse for a champion coming in and dropping 3 straight rounds. That's my response to the "you need to beat the champ decisively to win the belt" idea as well. Lastly, you can argue that the only reason Jones took the last 2 rounds was because Reyes knew he won the first 3 and thus fought more cautiously during the last 2 to avoid getting caught (which is perfectly reasonable within a 5 round fight). While Reyes might not have been "robbed" because weird Texas uses the outdated judging system, these arguments for why Jones supposedly "won" the fight are weak as fuck. He dropped 3 straight rounds in a 5 round fight, and you just can't get around that fact.
snippet.textOriginal: Apparently the judges in Texas score fights on the old rules, which heavily weigh octagon control (or allow judges to heavily weigh it). And Jones was moving forward practically the entire fight, even though for the first 3 rounds he was getting bombed. That's the only rational explanation I can conceive for the one judge's result. I still think Reyes won, and that judge's score was ridiculous. As for weighing the last two "championship" rounds more, I don't agree with that, because then that always allows the champion to do little for the first three rounds and save it all for the last two. I feel that in a 5 round fight, there's no excuse for a champion coming in and dropping 3 straight rounds. That's my response to the "you need to beat the champ decisively to win the belt" idea as well. Lastly, you can argue that the only reason Jones took the last 2 rounds was because Reyes knew he won the first 3 and thus fought more cautiously during the last 2 to avoid getting caught (which is perfectly reasonable within a 5 round fight). While Reyes might not have been "robbed" because weird Texas uses the outdated judging system, these arguments for why Jones supposedly "won" the fight are weak as fuck. He dropped 3 straight rounds in a 5 round fight, and you just can't get around that fact.

snippet.textDisplay:
That's a dumb point by Joe-Ro, the last two rounds shouldn't count for more cuz that's not "when the teachers stop the fight", the fight is stopped after the first round, where Jon Jones was getting his ass kicked; again after the second round it's stopped, where Jon Jones was getting his ass kicked... Jones got to go to his corner and regroup, in a real fight, you just go at it, there isn't a bell stopping it and 2 minute wait before you fight again.

Jon Jones lost this fight, stop making excuses.

snippet.textDisplay: I've only heard there arguments for Jones so far. It's either people saying that literally just walking forward won Jones the fight as if walking scores more than power punches and kicks landing on your chin. I welcome ALL of those people to go pick a fight on the street and try walking forward without throwing any punches or kicks and see if they win because of the walking. Maybe then they'll realize how stupid they sound. The next is saying only rounds 4 and 5 count and the first three don't matter. All that says is you don't understand how MMA is scored. If that's the case fighter A could land 50 clean power punches in the first three rounds to fighter B's 0 strikes but if fighter B lands one jab in both rounds 4 and 5 and fighter A doesn't then fighter B wins the fight. Again, that's insanely moronic. The last is arguing the two takedowns won Jones the fight. This means two things. It means if any fighter lands a takedown and the other fighter doesn't then the first fighter wins no matter what happens for the rest of the fight. It also means two takedowns with maybe 5 seconds total of ground control, 0 strikes thrown or landed and 0 submissions attempted or position advances is more effective in a fight than a fighter landing the cleaner, more effective strikes and landing WAY more of them. One guy was visibly hurt at least twice and was fighting to survive in several rounds. The other guy got a takedown that was immediately rendered ineffective as they were both back on their feet. I guess this is a wrestling match and the striker got points deducted while the wrestler earned points. Otherwise there's no explanation for it. Now, these three arguments clearly sound nonsensical to any intelligent person and yet they are the only three being given. Does anyone have a real argument?

snippet.textDisplay: It seems like the way to win a 5 round mma fight is to do the minimum to survive for 3 rounds and then win the last 2 based on just being less fatigued than the other guy who wasted his energy trying to win in the first 3 rounds. Not sure if that's a good thing or not but let's say they decide to make fights 7 or 20 rounds. What would happen? It would still come down to who can pace themselves for the end, vs people who try and blow their wad and finish the fight early. But you usually can't last the full fight if you try and finish early. The real savvy champs like Jones and GSP have figured out that its safer to just outlast your opponent and let them tire themselves out and then collect the decision. Just my opinion anyway. Reyes lost that fight when he couldn't finish it in round 1 basically, when it comes down to it. Two different strategies.
snippet.textOriginal: It seems like the way to win a 5 round mma fight is to do the minimum to survive for 3 rounds and then win the last 2 based on just being less fatigued than the other guy who wasted his energy trying to win in the first 3 rounds. Not sure if that's a good thing or not but let's say they decide to make fights 7 or 20 rounds. What would happen? It would still come down to who can pace themselves for the end, vs people who try and blow their wad and finish the fight early. But you usually can't last the full fight if you try and finish early. The real savvy champs like Jones and GSP have figured out that its safer to just outlast your opponent and let them tire themselves out and then collect the decision. Just my opinion anyway. Reyes lost that fight when he couldn't finish it in round 1 basically, when it comes down to it. Two different strategies.

snippet.textDisplay:
Joe Rogan is spot on with this, the scoring system needs to change!!! Open scoring of the rounds for the fighters to know where they stand in the fight while they're still in the octagon is also a great idea! (Makes no sense why it shouldn't be implemented)

I also agree that at the end of the fight, Jon was winning...either make the final rounds worth more (not sure how you do that exactly) or add more rounds like they have in boxing... in MMA all it takes is one moment, one slip up, if the opposition gets tired in later rounds, there will be less fights going to decision. (Capitalize)

Joe, you truly are the best MMA commentator to ever do it, hopefully the UFC listens and fixes these obvious tarnishes to this amazing sport which demands the upmost respect to the fighters... if it went 5 more rounds, no doubt in my mind Jon Jones would win the fight.

snippet.textDisplay:
These are some dum ass arguments including: "Jon won that fight. He impressed me with the shots he took" and "I feel like the last two rounds should count more". It's no street fight! It's five rounds and Reyes arguably won three. We know that Jon Jones is great, but we care about what happened in that particular fight.

P.S. I also feel like the second round was the one that was the closest.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
To use an argument that Jon would win if they go to death, because he was winning last two rounds, or that in a schoolyard a kid which was dominating the end wins, to justify claim that last rounds should be worth more, makes no sense. Why? Two reasons: 1. The rules are that you count each rounds separately and equally. 2. If they were going to fight to death or like in a school yard, there would be no breaks between rounds, which may very well mean that in the 8th minute of the fight (without a break after five minutes) JJ would have been KOd.
So, whichever way you take it, Dominick won the fight.
snippet.textOriginal:
To use an argument that Jon would win if they go to death, because he was winning last two rounds, or that in a schoolyard a kid which was dominating the end wins, to justify claim that last rounds should be worth more, makes no sense. Why? Two reasons: 1. The rules are that you count each rounds separately and equally. 2. If they were going to fight to death or like in  a school yard, there would be no breaks between rounds, which may very well mean that in the 8th minute of the fight (without a break after five minutes) JJ would have been KOd.
So, whichever way you take it, Dominick won the fight.

snippet.textDisplay:
Here is an easy way to score the fight. 'Who won the overall fight'. No round by round 10-9 must bullshit. Just judge damage and domination. NOT CONTROL, but domination. You laying on someone counts but it doesn't count for much, you being on top of someone and mauling them with strikes THATS domination. Easy as fuck.



Jon Jones wins the fight, he overall controlled the fight by the end and as Joe simply stated if the fight continues and has no time limit Jones wins that fight.


This boxing scoring system is a mess and never has nor ever will work for MMA.
snippet.textOriginal:
Here is an easy way to score the fight. 'Who won the overall fight'. No round by round 10-9 must bullshit. Just judge damage and domination. NOT CONTROL, but domination. You laying on someone counts but it doesn't count for much, you being on top of someone and mauling them with strikes THATS domination. Easy as fuck. 



Jon Jones wins the fight, he overall controlled the fight by the end and as Joe simply stated if the fight continues and has no time limit Jones wins that fight. 


This boxing scoring system is a mess and never has nor ever will work for MMA.

snippet.textDisplay: You cannot judge a fight based on the significant strikes landed statistics that are shared. In the current point system Jones outscored Reyes on octagon control and by moving forward more often than not. This points system is clearly flawed and does not favor counter strikers.
snippet.textOriginal: You cannot judge a fight based on the significant strikes landed statistics that are shared. In the current point system Jones outscored Reyes on octagon control and by moving forward more often than not. This points system is clearly flawed and does not favor counter strikers.

snippet.textDisplay:
Doesn't make sense that you would emphasize the end of the 5th round. You have to remember that the end of the 5th round takes place after 4 separate rest periods.
A real fight does not have rest periods. If anything, the person who had the advantage at the end of the 1st round is the person who would have most likely won the real fight. This is especially true if the end of that 1st round had someone dominant in a grappling position.
snippet.textOriginal:
